nexttext:
is the fundamental quasi-symmetric function introduced by Gessel \citep{Gessel}. In Section \ref{sec:ides}, we will apply Haglund, Morse, and Zabrocki's refinement \citep{compconj}, which was recently proved by Carlsson and Mellit \citep{compproof}.

In \citep{sqconj}, Loehr and Warrington conjectured a similar formula for $\nabla p_n$. They express this symmetric function as an enumeration of all preference functions. Their statistics are similar to those used in the Shuffle Conjecture. The word of a preference function, for example, is calculated just as the word of a parking function is: the cars are read from highest to lowest diagonal and from right to left within each diagonal. We will again write ${\operatorname{ides}}(Pr)$ for the inverse descent set of the word of a preference function $Pr$. The preference function on the right of Figure \ref{fig:pref} has word $5 \, 2 \, 3 \, 1 \, 4$ and ${\operatorname{ides}} = \{1,4\}.$

The ${\operatorname{dinv}}$ of a preference function has three components: the usual primary and secondary ${\operatorname{dinv}}$s (within any diagonals) and a new component that we will call tertiary ${\operatorname{dinv}}$. The tertiary ${\operatorname{dinv}}$ is simply the number of cars strictly below the main diagonal $y=x$. For example, the preference function on the right of Figure \ref{fig:pref} has ${\operatorname{dinv}} = 3$. That is, it has no primary ${\operatorname{dinv}}$, one secondary ${\operatorname{dinv}}$ (between cars $2$ and $5$), and two tertiary ${\operatorname{dinv}}$s (contributed by cars $1$ and $4$).

To compute the ${\operatorname{area}}$ of a preference function, we need to name diagonals. In particular, we will refer to the diagonal $y=x+k$ as the $k$-th diagonal. For any preference function $Pr$, let $l(Pr)$ be as large as possible so that the diagonal $y=x-l(Pr)$ is not empty. This is known as the deviation of the preference function. Note that $Pr$ is a parking function iff $l(Pr)=0$. Then a car of $Pr$ in diagonal $k$ contributes $k+l(Pr)$ to ${\operatorname{area}}(Pr)$. So in the left side of Figure \ref{fig:pref}, the deviation is $1$ and ${\operatorname{area}} = 4$. Note for a parking function, the two definitions introduced here for the ${\operatorname{area}}$, ${\operatorname{dinv}}$ and word statistics coincide.

Let ${\cal P}ref_n$ be the set of all preference functions on $n$ cars.
\begin{conjecture}[Loehr-Warrington] \label{conj:sq}

nexttext:
Therefore it is sufficient to prove our claim for $\tau$ with a single descent and $l=1$ (that is, for the case when the preference functions in question are contained in two diagonals).

Suppose $\tau \in S_n$ with a single descent. For a finite set $A$, let $A^\uparrow$ denote the word consisting of the elements of $A$ in increasing order. Then $\tau = B^\uparrow \, A^\uparrow$ for some disjoint $A,B$. Let $\lambda \subseteq |A| \times |B|$ be the partition whose $i$th part is the number of elements of $A$ which are smaller than the $i$-th largest element of $B$. Then $\lambda'$ is the partition whose $j$th part is the number of elements of $B$ which are larger than the $j$-th smallest element of $A$.

Let $w^{(l)}_i = w^{(l)}(c)$ for $c= \tau_{n+1-i}$. Then for $i$ from $1$ to $|A|$, $w^{(0)}_i = i$, and for $j$ from $1$ to $|B|$, $w^{(0)}_{|A|+j} =  \lambda_j + j-1$. Hence the $0$-schedule numbers of $\tau$ form $\{ ( \lambda + \delta_{|B|}) \cup \delta_{|A|+1} \} \setminus \{0\} $. On the other hand, for $i$ from $1$ to $|A|$, $w^{(1)}_i = \lambda'_{|A|-i+1} + |A|-i$, and for $j$ from $1$ to $|B|$, $w^{(1)}_{|A|+j} = j$. Then the $1$-schedule numbers of $\tau$ form $\{ ( \lambda' + \delta_{|A|}) \cup \delta_{|B|+1} \} \setminus \{0\}$.

For example, consider $\tau = 3 \, 4 \, 5 \, 8 \, 1 \, 2 \, 6 \, 7 \, 9$. Then $A = \{1,2,6,7,9\}$ and $B = \{3,4,5,8\}$. This gives $\lambda = (4,2,2,2)$ and $\lambda' = (4,4,1,1,0)$. Furthermore, we have

Suppose $\tau \in S_n$ with a single descent. For a finite set $A$, let $A^\uparrow$ denote the word consisting of the elements of $A$ in increasing order. Then $\tau = B^\uparrow \, A^\uparrow$ for some disjoint $A,B$. Let $\lambda \subseteq |A| \times |B|$ be the partition whose $i$th part is the number of elements of $A$ which are smaller than the $i$-th largest element of $B$. Then $\lambda'$ is the partition whose $j$th part is the number of elements of $B$ which are larger than the $j$-th smallest element of $A$.

Let $w^{(l)}_i = w^{(l)}(c)$ for $c= \tau_{n+1-i}$. Then for $i$ from $1$ to $|A|$, $w^{(0)}_i = i$, and for $j$ from $1$ to $|B|$, $w^{(0)}_{|A|+j} =  \lambda_j + j-1$. Hence the $0$-schedule numbers of $\tau$ form $\{ ( \lambda + \delta_{|B|}) \cup \delta_{|A|+1} \} \setminus \{0\} $. Then the $1$-schedule numbers of $\tau$ form $\{ ( \lambda' + \delta_{|A|}) \cup \delta_{|B|+1} \} \setminus \{0\}$.

\end{corollary}
\noindent Now we can relate the right hand side of this equation to $\nabla$ using a corollary of the recently-proven Compositional Shuffle Conjecture. More precisely, in \citep{compconj}, Haglund, Morse and Zabrocki refined the Shuffle Conjecture using the following plethystic symmetric function operators.

$$
\sum_{\substack{Pr \in {\cal P}ref_n \\ {\operatorname{diagword}}(Pr)=\tau}} t^{{\operatorname{area}}(Pr)} q^{{\operatorname{dinv}}(Pr)} Q_{{\operatorname{ides}}(Pr)}
= \frac{[n]_q}{[k]_q} \sum_{\substack{PF \in {\cal PF}_n \\ {\operatorname{diagword}}(PF)=\tau}} t^{{\operatorname{area}}(PF)} q^{{\operatorname{dinv}}(PF)} Q_{{\operatorname{ides}}(PF)}.
$$

\noindent Now we can relate the right hand side of this equation to $\nabla$ using a corollary of the recently-proven Compositional Shuffle Conjecture. More precisely, in \citep{compconj}, Haglund, Morse and Zabrocki refined the Shuffle Conjecture using the following plethystic symmetric function operators.
